moves.1. c4:
English
I did not play this game on GameKnot.com.  I played this person to person.
moves.1... e5 2. Nc3 g6:
This is a very slow move. It can give white the initiative d4! or Nf3!? I believe in the future, I'll play g6; Bg7; e5 or e5; Nc6; g6
Knowing my opponent, I think he wouldn't even play the attacking move mention.
moves.3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 Nc6: Both of us are now controlling each others (4th & 5th rank) d-pawn square
moves.5. d3: I am not sure if he played this move or e4 right away, but I know what it transposed to
moves.5... d6 6. e4: My foe decieded to play the Nimzo-Botvinik system,  I learned of this system while my days playing at a chess club in seattle.  I've seen a couple of games  with white winning by using this system and heard it is a universal system for white.  I also seen a couple of games with black winning.  The setup I use, I'm black, is what Gregory Serper used to beat a young kid Michael Lee in Wa state Championship.  However, I did not play Nh5 and Instead playing Nd7 incorrectly playing the system.  Kasparov also played this line as black a couple of times
moves.6... f5: Now I am setting up a King's Indian formation without having to move my knight twice to play f5.
moves.9... a5 10. Rb1 Be6 11. Bg5 Qd7 12. Nd5: This can lead to a wasted tempo via B/Nxf6; Bxf6 and B/Nxf6 and then I have to move my rook again.  This is where my knowledge of the Serper game left me.  Here he played Nh5 for what reason, I do not know.
moves.13. b4 axb4 14. axb4 Ne7: ?  Now I made a mistake.  I did not want to move the rook and surrender the a-file to White's Rook.  So, I wanted to attack the Nd5; c6, but this allows white to win the b-Pawn
moves.16... gxf5 17. Bxb7: This is when I said, "darn it, I knew I should have played Raf8"
moves.18... Qd7: Trying to trap his bishop, in vain.
moves.19. b5 e4 20. Nd4: ?!  He gives me a extra move.
moves.21... Qc8: I did not want to pin my queen against his dark squared bishop on e7, restricting the mobility of my knight.  In the future, I knew he was going to be useful on e4.
moves.22. Ra1: !  I foresaw the doom of my Queen
moves.22... Bxc4: !  I decided to go into the endgame
moves.26. Nxf5 Rxf5 27. Rxe4 Ra1 28. Qxa1 Bxa1: ??   Missing the chance to queen my pawn.  I played this on a real chess board  and did not calculate  deep enough.
moves.30. Kf2: Now I can't queen my pawn
